meanings.sent1: The loud noise helped to fleme the birds from the tree.
meanings.sent2: The scarecrow was placed in the field to fleme away the pesky crows.
meanings.sent3: The magician used a wand to fleme the rabbit out of the hat.
meanings.sent4: The bright light seemed to fleme the shadows into the corners of the room.
meanings.sent5: The brave knight rode into battle to fleme the enemy forces.

meanings.definition: To put to flight or rout.
meanings.sent1: The sudden appearance of the dog fleme the squirrel up the tree.
meanings.sent2: The loud noise made the deer fleme from the clearing.
meanings.sent3: The unexpected clap of thunder fleme the cat off the windowsill.
meanings.sent4: The strong wind seemed to fleme the leaves from the trees.
meanings.sent5: The bright light fleme the shadows away from the dark alley.

meanings.definition: To cause to vanish or disappear.
meanings.sent1: The magician's trick seemed to fleme the coin from his hand.
meanings.sent2: The fog slowly began to fleme the outline of the distant mountains.
meanings.sent3: The disappearing act on stage made the rabbit fleme from the hat.
meanings.sent4: The setting sun started to fleme the colors from the sky.
meanings.sent5: The artist used a brush to fleme the edges of the painting.
